Resources for DHM Faculty

Dear New Faculty:

Welcome aboard!  We are looking forward to your joining the Division of Hospital Medicine.

Below are housekeeping items that need to be completed at least a week before your start date, unless otherwise noted:

  1. DHM orientation - You will be contacted for an orientation with Brad Sharpe and Maria Novelero. During this orientation, Elaine Lee will cover billing and documentation.

  2. HR and benefits orientation - You will receive an email inviting you to attend a benefits orientation where you will fill out payroll forms and receive information on your benefits and instructions on how to enroll. Please plan to attend one of these sessions. If you do not receive this email, please contact Steve Gordon at steven.gordon@ucsf.edu or 514-3211.

  3. Time study - All UCSF Physicians are required to complete time studies in order for the clinical departments to receive Medi-Cal SPA reimbursement under the State Plan Amendment 05-023 & Medi-Cal Hospital/Uninsured Care Demonstration (No. 11-W-00193-9) project. As part of national Medicaid reform, these funds help bridge the gap between the reimbursement paid by the state for Medi-Cal patients and the actual cost of providing care to this population. In order to participate in this program, all UCSF physicians who report time are required to complete a brief training course before completing the time study form. Log in with your EIN or provider ID and search for Time Study: https://learningcenter.ucsfmedicalcenter.org/. Read the FAQs.

  4. Online APeX training module: http://apextraining.ucsfmedicalcenter.org/providers/ Click Inpatient/ED/PUC → Click Inpatient → Click Heavy Orders → Click Log In to see which courses you've already completed & enter your EIN → Complete all online courses (must be completed prior to classroom training).
    Classroom training: Register for an instructor-led course, which requires in-person attendance. Online courses must be completed prior to classroom training (courses are only offered twice a month).

  5. Online training modules: https://learningcenter.ucsfmedicalcenter.org/
    • Safety Training Infection Control and Restraint
    • Patient Safety & Quality of Care: Central Venous Catheter Insertion Practice (if you've requested this privilege)
    • Ethics Briefing

    Your employee/provider ID is needed for log-in and will be forwarded to you once its sets up. The training needs to be completed 3 weeks before start date.

  6. HIPAA online training https://domhr.ucsf.edu/hipaa.html

  7. Orientation on hospitalist clinical services - Please contact Brad Sharpe for Moffitt-Long Medical Service Hospitalist Service at sharpeb@medicine.ucsf.edu; Sanjay Reddy for Nighttime/CHF/Heme-BMT Hospital Services at sreddy@medicine.ucsf.edu; Diane Sliwka for Mt. Zion Medical Service at dsliwka@medicine.ucsf.edu; or Quinny Cheng for Neurosurgery Co-management Service at quinny@medicine.ucsf.edu.

  8. Webpacs - Your application is being processed. Upon set-up, please contact 502-5838 for login and password.

  9. MyAccess is UCSF's single-sign on service that enables you to access a variety of applications via a common user id and password. Once you sign in to MyAccess, you will be able to browse and link to a broad list of UCSF applications, including Advance which is an online tool for academic appointments and advancements. Please request MyAcess here: https://myaccess.ucsf.edu/eai/UCAlias/jsp/home.jsp.

  10. ID badge - Please send me your preferred name for your badge. I will let you know when you can request an appointment online at http://police.ucsf.edu or by phone at 476-2088. WEID is located at 500 Parnassus Avenue, Room G-18.

  11. Clinical schedule - If you would like to confirm your clinical schedule, please contact Christine Lam at lamc@medicine.ucsf.edu or 415-885-3723. You can also access all DHM clinical schedules online. Go to https://www.amion.com/ with the password "ucsf hosp".

  12. For your reference, you contact information at work will be:
                Phone number: 415-476-XXXX
                Fax number: 415-476-4818
                Mailing address: 533 Parnassus Avenue, Suite U127a, Box 0131, SF, CA 94143-0131

Thank you in advance for your cooperation and understanding. I would be glad to hear your feedback on how we can improve the orientation process and make your transition smoother and easier. Welcome again!

Best regards,

Kat

Resources for DHM Faculty

Dear New Faculty:

Welcome to the Division of Hospital Medicine! I will send you a copy of your offer letter shortly. Below are the details and instructions for the required paperwork to process your credentials/privileges and academic appointment:

Please print, sign and return documents for medical staff privileges and billing credentials at least 10 weeks before your start date.  The sooner your completed applications are received, the faster they are submitted to the appropriate offices for processing.  Please note that the review process can take at least 3 months.  It is important to give as accurate and complete information as requested on the forms to prevent delays in the review process.  Please let Kat Li (contact info below) know if you have any questions or if you are unable to download the forms (it is best to copy and paste the links onto the web browser).

Please provide as detailed and complete as information as possible on all forms. If there are fields that you don’t know (eg, your UC ID no, phone number, location, etc.), please leave them blank and we will complete them for you.

Medical Staff Privileges:

Step 1: Download and complete the Medical Staff Application form

Step 2: Review checklist (instruction page of downloaded form)

Step 3: Double check:

  • Sign and date pg. 7-9 (3 signatures)
  • Mark whether or not you’ll use/supervise the use of fluoro/x-ray equipment (pg. 4)

Step 4: Download the Privileges form

Step 5: Double check:

  • Complete and sign privileges (pg. 9)
  • For central Line placement privilege, applicants must complete a module at the learning center (you will receive a provider ID number after application is reviewed by the Medical Staff Office. Click here for the module.

In addition – did you include…

  • Your CA medical license
  • Your DEA certificate
  • Your CV in mm/yy format for all training and work history
  • Your current photograph (e.g. CA driver’s license)

Step 6: Review/Download Medical Staff Bylaws and the Medical Staff Rules & Regulations

**************************
Billing Credentials:

Step 1:  Prior to health plan enrollment each UCSF provider is now required to procure a National Provider Identifier.  An NPI is required for health plan enrollment.  Apply for your NPI online.

Step 2: Download Physician, Healthplan Enrollment application.  Complete, submit via email, and print out to sign signature pages. Note: please allow time for download due to large file.

Step 3: Double check:

  • That you have signed all signature pages (one page is duplicated purposely) and submit completed application with original signatures
  • Include legible photocopies of your
    * California professional license
    * Photo ID (passport, driver’s license)
    * Medical doctorate diploma
    * Printed email confirmation of your NPI

**************************
Academic Appointment:

  • Complete and sign Attachment A
  • Complete and sign UC Biography form (HR will not accept “see attached CV”)
  • Print and sign discussion checklist
  • Curriculum Vitae. Please indicate the date CV was prepared on first page of CV. CV must include employment history with dates.  Please use exact academic title and series, e.g. Assistant Clinical Professor of Medicine and Anesthesia; Associate Clinical Professor of Medicine, etc. See sample format.
  • List of all current intramural/extramural grants, if applicable.
  • A one-page description of your teaching and mentoring activities, including total hours spent annually for academic years 09/10, 10/11 and anticipated 11/12. See sample.
  • A one-page, single-spaced description of University and public service (lectures, grand rounds, radio and TV spots, committees, etc.). See sample.
  • Intramural & Extramural letters of recommendation. In consultation with your Division Chief, please provide us with the names, titles, addresses and emails of 3-5 internal referees and 3-5 external referees who are leaders in your field and have firsthand knowledge of your achievements. Please see Departmental Guideline for Identifying References here. Download template.
  • Provide names, addresses and emails of 5 to 7 students (medical students, housestaff, postdocs) who will attest to your teaching talents. Please note that providing the student's home address is preferred as it is often a more efficient and reliable method for contacting the students. 

**************************
Other forms:

  • STOR/CDS (access to patient medical records)
  • Webpacs account (access to radiology computing resources)
  • Parking application (please note that there is currently a waitlist and parking is not guaranteed at this time)
  • ID card
  • Computer security account
  • Health science compensation plan statement

To simplify the process, Kat Li will be your main contact person for all required paperwork. Return completed medical staff membership application, privileges forms, provider health plan application, academic appointment paperwork, and miscellaneous forms along with the proper attachments/documentations to:

Kat Li
Division of Hospital Medicine
University of California San Francisco
533 Parnassus Avenue, U112
Box 0131
San Francisco, CA 94143-0131

Questions?  Contact Kat at 415-476-4854 or email kli@medicine.ucsf.edu

*Please make copies of the applications and forms for your record.

Thank you in advance for your cooperation and understanding. I would be glad to hear feedback from you on how we can improve the appointment and credentialing process and make your transition smoother and easier. Welcome again!

Best regards,

Kat

Resources for DHM Faculty

Dear New Faculty:

Welcome aboard!  We are looking forward to your joining the Division of Hospital Medicine.

Below are housekeeping items that need to be completed at least a week before your start date, unless otherwise noted:

  1. DHM orientation - You will be contacted for an orientation with Brad Sharpe and Maria Novelero. During this orientation, Elaine Lee will cover billing and documentation.

  2. HR and benefits orientation - You will receive an email inviting you to attend a benefits orientation where you will fill out payroll forms and receive information on your benefits and instructions on how to enroll. Please plan to attend one of these sessions. If you do not receive this email, please contact Steve Gordon at steven.gordon@ucsf.edu or 514-3211.

  3. Time study - All UCSF Physicians are required to complete time studies in order for the clinical departments to receive Medi-Cal SPA reimbursement under the State Plan Amendment 05-023 & Medi-Cal Hospital/Uninsured Care Demonstration (No. 11-W-00193-9) project. As part of national Medicaid reform, these funds help bridge the gap between the reimbursement paid by the state for Medi-Cal patients and the actual cost of providing care to this population. In order to participate in this program, all UCSF physicians who report time are required to complete a brief training course before completing the time study form. Log in with your EIN or provider ID and search for Time Study: https://learningcenter.ucsfmedicalcenter.org/. Read the FAQs.

  4. Online APeX training module: http://apextraining.ucsfmedicalcenter.org/providers/ Click Inpatient/ED/PUC → Click Inpatient → Click Heavy Orders → Click Log In to see which courses you've already completed & enter your EIN → Complete all online courses (must be completed prior to classroom training).
    Classroom training: Register for an instructor-led course, which requires in-person attendance. Online courses must be completed prior to classroom training (courses are only offered twice a month).

  5. Online training modules: https://learningcenter.ucsfmedicalcenter.org/
    • Safety Training Infection Control and Restraint
    • Patient Safety & Quality of Care: Central Venous Catheter Insertion Practice (if you've requested this privilege)
    • Ethics Briefing

    Your employee/provider ID is needed for log-in and will be forwarded to you once its sets up. The training needs to be completed 3 weeks before start date.

  6. HIPAA online training https://domhr.ucsf.edu/hipaa.html

  7. Orientation on hospitalist clinical services - Please contact Brad Sharpe for Moffitt-Long Medical Service Hospitalist Service at sharpeb@medicine.ucsf.edu; Sanjay Reddy for Nighttime/CHF/Heme-BMT Hospital Services at sreddy@medicine.ucsf.edu; Diane Sliwka for Mt. Zion Medical Service at dsliwka@medicine.ucsf.edu; or Quinny Cheng for Neurosurgery Co-management Service at quinny@medicine.ucsf.edu.

  8. Webpacs - Your application is being processed. Upon set-up, please contact 502-5838 for login and password.

  9. MyAccess is UCSF's single-sign on service that enables you to access a variety of applications via a common user id and password. Once you sign in to MyAccess, you will be able to browse and link to a broad list of UCSF applications, including Advance which is an online tool for academic appointments and advancements. Please request MyAcess here: https://myaccess.ucsf.edu/eai/UCAlias/jsp/home.jsp.

  10. ID badge - Please send me your preferred name for your badge. I will let you know when you can request an appointment online at http://police.ucsf.edu or by phone at 476-2088. WEID is located at 500 Parnassus Avenue, Room G-18.

  11. Clinical schedule - If you would like to confirm your clinical schedule, please contact Christine Lam at lamc@medicine.ucsf.edu or 415-885-3723. You can also access all DHM clinical schedules online. Go to https://www.amion.com/ with the password "ucsf hosp".

  12. For your reference, you contact information at work will be:
                Phone number: 415-476-XXXX
                Fax number: 415-476-4818
                Mailing address: 533 Parnassus Avenue, Suite U127a, Box 0131, SF, CA 94143-0131

Thank you in advance for your cooperation and understanding. I would be glad to hear your feedback on how we can improve the orientation process and make your transition smoother and easier. Welcome again!

Best regards,

Kat

Resources for DHM Faculty

Dear New Faculty:

Welcome to the Division of Hospital Medicine! I will send you a copy of your offer letter shortly. Below are the details and instructions for the required paperwork to process your credentials/privileges and academic appointment:

Please print, sign and return documents for medical staff privileges and billing credentials at least 10 weeks before your start date.  The sooner your completed applications are received, the faster they are submitted to the appropriate offices for processing.  Please note that the review process can take at least 3 months.  It is important to give as accurate and complete information as requested on the forms to prevent delays in the review process.  Please let Kat Li (contact info below) know if you have any questions or if you are unable to download the forms (it is best to copy and paste the links onto the web browser).

Please provide as detailed and complete as information as possible on all forms. If there are fields that you don’t know (eg, your UC ID no, phone number, location, etc.), please leave them blank and we will complete them for you.

Medical Staff Privileges:

Step 1: Download and complete the Medical Staff Application form

Step 2: Review checklist (instruction page of downloaded form)

Step 3: Double check:

  • Sign and date pg. 7-9 (3 signatures)
  • Mark whether or not you’ll use/supervise the use of fluoro/x-ray equipment (pg. 4)

Step 4: Download the Privileges form

Step 5: Double check:

  • Complete and sign privileges (pg. 9)
  • For central Line placement privilege, applicants must complete a module at the learning center (you will receive a provider ID number after application is reviewed by the Medical Staff Office. Click here for the module.

In addition – did you include…

  • Your CA medical license
  • Your DEA certificate
  • Your CV in mm/yy format for all training and work history
  • Your current photograph (e.g. CA driver’s license)

Step 6: Review/Download Medical Staff Bylaws and the Medical Staff Rules & Regulations

**************************
Billing Credentials:

Step 1:  Prior to health plan enrollment each UCSF provider is now required to procure a National Provider Identifier.  An NPI is required for health plan enrollment.  Apply for your NPI online.

Step 2: Download Physician, Healthplan Enrollment application.  Complete, submit via email, and print out to sign signature pages. Note: please allow time for download due to large file.

Step 3: Double check:

  • That you have signed all signature pages (one page is duplicated purposely) and submit completed application with original signatures
  • Include legible photocopies of your
    * California professional license
    * Photo ID (passport, driver’s license)
    * Medical doctorate diploma
    * Printed email confirmation of your NPI

**************************
Academic Appointment:

  • Complete and sign Attachment A
  • Complete and sign UC Biography form (HR will not accept “see attached CV”)
  • Print and sign discussion checklist
  • Curriculum Vitae. Please indicate the date CV was prepared on first page of CV. CV must include employment history with dates.  Please use exact academic title and series, e.g. Assistant Clinical Professor of Medicine and Anesthesia; Associate Clinical Professor of Medicine, etc. See sample format.
  • List of all current intramural/extramural grants, if applicable.
  • A one-page description of your teaching and mentoring activities, including total hours spent annually for academic years 09/10, 10/11 and anticipated 11/12. See sample.
  • A one-page, single-spaced description of University and public service (lectures, grand rounds, radio and TV spots, committees, etc.). See sample.

**************************
Other forms:

  • STOR/CDS (access to patient medical records)
  • Webpacs account (access to radiology computing resources)
  • Parking application (please note that there is currently a waitlist and parking is not guaranteed at this time)
  • ID card
  • Computer security account
  • Health science compensation plan statement

To simplify the process, Kat Li will be your main contact person for all required paperwork. Return completed medical staff membership application, privileges forms, provider health plan application, academic appointment paperwork, and miscellaneous forms along with the proper attachments/documentations to:

Kat Li
Division of Hospital Medicine
University of California San Francisco
533 Parnassus Avenue, U112
Box 0131
San Francisco, CA 94143-0131

Questions?  Contact Kat at 415-476-4854 or email kli@medicine.ucsf.edu

*Please make copies of the applications and forms for your record.

Thank you in advance for your cooperation and understanding. I would be glad to hear feedback from you on how we can improve the appointment and credentialing process and make your transition smoother and easier. Welcome again!

Best regards,

Kat

Resources for DHM Faculty

Dear New Faculty:

Welcome aboard!  We are looking forward to your joining the Division of Hospital Medicine.

Below are housekeeping items that need to be completed at least a week before your start date, unless otherwise noted:

1) Please meet with Michelle Chen in HR at least 2 weeks before your start date in order to obtain your ID, email, and computer access in a timely matter. Please contact her at mchen@medicine.ucsf.edu or 415-502-1854 to schedule an HR orientation.

2) Online Training Modules for UCare (the electronic clinical system that generates electronic medical record) at https://learningcenter.ucsfmedicalcenter.org/. You will need your provider ID for log-in. I will forward this to you as soon as the Medical Staff Office sets it up.

3) HIPAA Online Training - http://www.ucsf.edu/hipaa/

4) Orientation with Elaine Lee on billing and documentation – Please contact Elaine at eklee@medicine.ucsf.edu or 415-502-2714.

5) Orientation with Tom Gardner on dictation and UCare set-up (UCare is the main hospital computer system which contains labs, nursing documentation, inpatient physician notes, team and personal lists for more details visit: http://ucare.ucsfmedicalcenter.org/) - Please contact Tom at tomg@medicine.ucsf.edu or 415-353-1731. Elaine Lee can help coordinate this meeting.

6) Orientation on hospitalist clinical services – Please contact Brad Sharpe for Moffitt-Long Medical Service Hospitalist Service at sharpeb@medicine.ucsf.edu or 514-2198; Michelle Mourad for Oncology/CHF Hospital Services at michelle.mourad@ucsf.edu or 476-2264; Heather Whelan for Mt. Zion Medical Service at hwhelan@medicine.ucsf.edu or 476-6759; or Quinny Cheng for Neurosurgery Co-management Service at quinny@medicine.ucsf.edu or 502-4210.

7)  STOR, UCare, and Webpacs – Your applications are being processed. Upon set-up, please contact 415-353-2189 for STOR training; 415-514-4100 to obtain UCare login and password; and 415-502-5838 for Webpacs login and password.

8) White coat – The division will pay for your first white coat, you are responsible for subsequent coats and laundry service. Please send me your receipt for reimbursement. If you wish, you may order from the UCSF bookstore at http://www.webmedbooks.com/ucsf/content/browse.aspx/id=115918/.
The division’s standard 2 line embroidery is:  
Your name and title(s) for example: Andy Cheng, MD, MPH
Hospital Medicine

9) Parking – Your application for parking is being processed.  We will let you know as soon as parking is assigned. Please note that there is currently a waitlist for the main hospital parking lot.  Surge/woods lot may be an option.  Shuttle services available and parking in main garage from 4:45-8am are offered. Please see website for more details: http://www.campuslifeservices.ucsf.edu/transportation/parking/permit/

10) ID form and new hire binder – Please set up a time to meet with me. To obtain ID, request an appointment online at http://police.ucsf.edu. Their phone number is 415-476-2088 and location is 500 Parnassus Ave, Room G-18. Your UCID number will be assigned after you meet with HR.

11) You can access your medicine account via the web at https://exchange.ucsf.edu/. If you need more assistance please contact the DOM Helpdesk at 476-6827 or OAAIS Service Desk at 514-4100, option 2.

12) Clinical schedule – If you would like to confirm your clinical schedule, please contact Christine Lam at lamc@medicine.ucsf.edu or 415-885-3723.

13) Business cards – If you would like business cards, please let contact Oralia Schatzman at oralias@medicine.ucsf.edu or 415-502-1414.

14)  For your reference, you contact information at work will be:
            Phone number: 415-476-XXXX
            Fax number: 415-476-4818
            Mailing address: Box 0131, Suite U112, 533 Parnassus Avenue, SF, CA 94143-0131

Thank you in advance for your cooperation and understanding. I would be glad to hear your feedback on how we can improve the orientation process and make your transition smoother and easier. Welcome again!

Best regards,

Kat

Welcome to the Division of Hospital Medicine! I will send you a copy of your contract letter shortly. Below are the details and instructions for the required paperwork to process your credentials/privileges and academic appointment:

Resources for DHM Fellow

Dear New Fellow:

Welcome aboard!  We are looking forward to your joining the Division of Hospital Medicine.

Below are housekeeping items that need to be completed at least a week before your start date, unless otherwise noted:

  1. DHM orientation - You will be contacted for an orientation with Brad Sharpe and Maria Novelero. During this orientation, Elaine Lee will cover billing.

  2. Time study - All UCSF Physicians are required to complete time studies in order for the clinical departments to receive Medi-Cal SPA reimbursement under the State Plan Amendment 05-023 & Medi-Cal Hospital/Uninsured Care Demonstration (No. 11-W-00193-9) project. As part of national Medicaid reform, these funds help bridge the gap between the reimbursement paid by the state for Medi-Cal patients and the actual cost of providing care to this population. In order to participate in this program, all UCSF physicians who report time are required to complete a brief training course before completing the time study form.Log in with your EIN or provider ID and search for Time Study: https://learningcenter.ucsfmedicalcenter.org/. Read the FAQs.

  3. Online APeX training module: http://apextraining.ucsfmedicalcenter.org/providers/ Click Inpatient/ED/PUC → Click Inpatient → Click Heavy Orders → Click Log In to see which courses you've already completed & enter your EIN → Complete all online courses (must be completed prior to classroom training).
    Classroom training: Register for an instructor-led course, which requires in-person attendance. Online courses must be completed prior to classroom training (courses are only offered twice a month).

  4. Online training modules: https://learningcenter.ucsfmedicalcenter.org/
    • Safety Training Infection Control and Restraint
    • Patient Safety & Quality of Care: Central Venous Catheter Insertion Practice (if you've requested this privilege)
    • Ethics Briefing

    Your employee/provider ID is needed for log-in and will be forwarded to you once its sets up. The training needs to be completed 3 weeks before start date.

  5. HIPAA online training https://domhr.ucsf.edu/hipaa.html

  6. Orientation on hospitalist clinical services - Please contact Brad Sharpe for Moffitt-Long Medical Service Hospitalist Service at sharpeb@medicine.ucsf.edu; Sanjay Reddy for Nighttime/CHF/Heme-BMT Hospital Services at sreddy@medicine.ucsf.edu; Diane Sliwka for Mt. Zion Medical Service at dsliwka@medicine.ucsf.edu; or Quinny Cheng for Neurosurgery Co-management Service at quinny@medicine.ucsf.edu.

  7. Webpacs - Your application is being processed. Upon set-up, please contact 502-5838 for login and password.

  8. MyAcess is UCSF's single-sign on service that enables you to access a variety of applications via a common user id and password. Once you sign in to MyAccess, you will be able to browse and link to a broad list of UCSF applications, including MyExpense which is an online tool for reimbursement. Please request MyAccess here: https://myaccess.ucsf.edu/eai/UCAlias/jsp/home.jsp.

  9. ID badge - Please send me your preferred name for your badge. I will let you know when you can request an appointment online at http://police.ucsf.edu or by phone at 476-2088. WEID is located at 500 Parnassus Avenue, Room G-18.

  10. Clinical schedule - If you would like to confirm your clinical schedule, please contact Christine Lam at lamc@medicine.ucsf.edu or 415-885-3723. You can also access all DHM clinical schedules online. Go to https://www.amion.com/ with the password "ucsf hosp".

  11. For your reference, you contact information at work will be:
                Phone number: 415-476-XXXX
                Fax number: 415-476-4818
                Mailing address: 533 Parnassus Avenue, Suite U127a, Box 0131, SF, CA 94143-0131

Thank you in advance for your cooperation and understanding. I would be glad to hear your feedback on how we can improve the orientation process and make your transition smoother and easier. Welcome again!

Best regards,

Kat

Please print, sign and return documents for medical staff privileges and billing credentials at least 10 weeks before your start date.  The sooner your completed applications are received, the faster they are submitted to the appropriate offices for processing.  Please note that the review process can take at least 3 months.  It is important to give as accurate and complete information as requested on the forms to prevent delays in the review process.  Please let Kat Li (contact info below) know if you have any questions or if you are unable to download the forms.   • If you already have a NPI number please fill out NPI form

  • List of all current intramural/extramural grants, if applicable.
  • A one-page description of your teaching and mentoring activities, including total hours spent annually for academic years 07/08, 08/09 and anticipated 09/10. See sample.

San Francisco has a plethora of museums, galleries, theaters, and science attractions to choose from. Whether you’re in the mood for exploring a roof-top garden or listening to singing winds along the coast, San Francisco has something for everyone.

    • Safety Training Infection Control and Restraint
    • Patient Safety & Quality of Care: Central Venous Catheter Insertion Practice (if you've requested this privilege)
    • AIDET SMiLe
    • For New Employees - please also complete a) Compliance Briefing: UC Ethical Values & Conduct b) HIPAA 101-Privacy and Security for New UCSF Faculty, Staff, Trainnees, Students, and Volunteers
  6. Orientation on hospitalist clinical services - Please contact Brad Sharpe for Moffitt-Long Medical Service Hospitalist Service at Bradley.Sharpe@ucsf.edu; Sanjay Reddy for Nighttime and CHF Hospital Services at Sanjay.Reddy@ucsf.edu; John Dzundza for Heme-BMT Hospital Services at John.Dzundza@ucsf.edu; Diane Sliwka for Goldman Medical Service at Diane.Sliwka@ucsf.edu; or Quinny Cheng for Mission Bay and Neurosurgery Co-management Service at Quinny.Cheng@ucsf.edu; Steve Pantilat for Palliative Care Service at Steve.Pantilat@ucsf.edu; Andy Lai for Procedure Service at Andrew.Lai@ucsf.edu.

  7. MyAccess is UCSF's single-sign on service that enables you to access a variety of applications via a common user id and password. Once you sign in to MyAccess, you will be able to browse and link to a broad list of UCSF applications, including Advance which is an online tool for academic appointments and advancements. Please request MyAcess here: https://myaccess.ucsf.edu/eai/UCAlias/jsp/home.jsp.

  8. ID badge - Please send me your preferred name for your badge. I will let you know when you can request an appointment online at http://police.ucsf.edu or by phone at 476-2088. WEID is located at 500 Parnassus Avenue, Room G-18.

  9. Clinical schedule - If you would like to confirm your clinical schedule, please contact Christine Lam at lamc@medicine.ucsf.edu or 415-885-3723. You can also access all DHM clinical schedules online. Go to https://www.amion.com/ with the password "ucsf hosp".

  10. For your reference, you contact information at work will be:
                Phone number: 415-476-XXXX
                Fax number: 415-476-4818
                Mailing address: 533 Parnassus Avenue, Suite U127, Box 0131, SF, CA 94143-0131

Thank you in advance for your cooperation and understanding. I would be glad to hear your feedback on how we can improve the orientation process and make your transition smoother and easier. Welcome again!

Best regards,

Kat

Parks and Outside Activities

Even in the middle of big city you can find lots of nature parks to escape the hustle and bustle of city life.

Golden Gate Park: http://www.sftravel.com/ggpark.html

San Francisco Botanical Gardens: http://www.sfbotanicalgarden.org/

San Francisco Conservatory of Flowers: http://www.conservatoryofflowers.org/

Stow Lake: http://www.yelp.com/biz/stow-lake-boat-and-bike-rentals-san-francisco

Twin Peaks: http://www.sftravel.com/twinpeakssanfrancisco.html

Shakespeare Garden: http://www.yelp.com/biz/shakespeare-garden-san-francisco

Maritime National Park: http://www.nps.gov/safr/

Find out which parks are dog-friendly here: http://www.sfdogparks.com/

SF Attractions

San Francisco is known for its array of dining choices, cultural landmarks, and progressive thinking. Life in the city is truly diverse; each neighborhood encompasses its own microcosm of foods, styles, and activities. There is so much to San Francisco that at times it can feel overwhelming. Here is a guide to some of our favorite things to do, eat, and see in San Francisco.

Shopping

There are as many shopping opportunities in San Francisco as sight-seeing attractions. Each neighborhood has its own niche shops and boutiques. And of course, there are great shopping districts for every kind of taste.

Westfield Shopping Center: http://westfield.com/sanfrancisco/

Stonestown Galleria: http://www.stonestowngalleria.com/

Chestnut Street: http://www.chestnutshop.com/

Union Square: http://www.unionsquareshop.com/

Embarcadero Center: http://www.embarcaderocenter.com/ec/

Haight Street: http://www.haightshop.com/

Popular Destinations

A few destinations stick out in everyone’s mind when they think of San Francisco, and for good reason, these attractions have been SF favorites for decades.

Fisherman’s Wharf: http://www.fishermanswharf.org/

Pier 39: http://www.pier39.com/index.cfm

Union Street: http://www.unionstreetshop.com/

Ghiradelli Square: http://www.ghirardellisq.com/

Golden Gate Bridge: http://www.goldengatebridge.org/visitors/

Alcatraz: http://www.alcatrazcruises.com/ 

Grace Cathedral: http://www.gracecathedral.org/welcome/overview/

Coit Tower: http://www.sftravel.com/coit-tower-san-francisco.html

Painted Ladies: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Painted_Ladies

Resources for DHM Faculty

Dear New Faculty:

Welcome to the Division of Hospital Medicine! I will send you a copy of your offer letter shortly. Below are the details and instructions for the required paperwork to process your credentials/privileges and academic appointment:

Please complete the online application (UC Me) for medical staff privileges and return completed signed documents for billing credentials at least 10 weeks before your start date. The sooner your completed applications are received, the faster they are routed to the appropriate offices for processing. Please note that the review process can take at least 3 months. It is important to give as accurate and complete information as requested on the forms to prevent delays in the review process. Please let Kat Li (contact info below) know if you have any questions or if you are unable to download the forms.

Please provide as detailed and complete as information as possible on all forms. You may leave fields that you don’t know (eg, your UC ID no, phone number, location, etc.) blank.

Medical Staff Privileges:

Step 1: The medical staff office will create your log in and email instructions on how to access UC Me.

Step 2: Download the top five UC Me tips.

**************************
Billing Credentials:

Step 1: Prior to health plan enrollment each UCSF provider is now required to procure a National Provider Identifier. An NPI is required for health plan enrollment. Apply for your NPI online.

Step 2: The Physician, Healthplan Enrollment application is part of your UCMe application. Complete the form as instructed and print out form to sign signature pages. Note: duplicate pages are intentional.

Step 3: Double check:

  • That you have signed all signature pages and submit completed application with original signatures
  • Include legible photocopies of your
    * California medical pocket-license (website printout unaccepted)
    * Driver’s license issued in the US
    * California home address

**************************
Academic Appointment:

  • Stephen Gordon, our HR specialist, will email you instructions to log into Advance (online tool for academic appointments and advancements) to complete the online application
  • Print and sign the Discussion Checklist (Clinical Instructors and Assistant Clinical Professors only)

**************************
Other forms:

  • Parking application (please note that there is currently a waitlist and parking is not guaranteed at this time)
  • Computer security account

To simplify the process, Kat Li will be your main contact person for all required paperwork. Return completed medical staff membership pre-application, provider health plan application, and miscellaneous forms along with the proper attachments/documentations to:

Kat Li
Division of Hospital Medicine
University of California San Francisco
533 Parnassus Avenue, U112
Box 0131
San Francisco, CA 94143-0131

Questions?  Contact Kat at 415-476-4854 or email kli@medicine.ucsf.edu

*Please make copies of the applications and forms for your record.

Thank you in advance for your cooperation and understanding. I would be glad to hear feedback from you on how we can improve the appointment and credentialing process and make your transition smoother and easier. Welcome again!

Best regards,

Kat

Resources for DHM Faculty

Dear New Faculty:

Welcome aboard!  We are looking forward to your joining the Division of Hospital Medicine!

Below are housekeeping items that need to be completed at least a week before your start date, unless otherwise noted:

1) Please meet with Michelle Chen in HR at least 2 weeks before your start date in order to obtain your ID, email, and computer access in a timely matter.  Please contact her at mchen@medicine.ucsf.edu or 415-502-1854 to schedule an HR orientation.

2) Online Training Modules for UCare (the electronic clinical system that generates electronic medical record) at http://cade.ucsfmedicalcenter.org/lmw/
You will need your provider ID for log-in. This will be forwarded to you as soon as the UCSF Medical Staff Office sets it up.

3) HIPAA Online Training - http://www.ucsf.edu/hipaa/

4) Orientation with Elaine Lee on billing and documentation – Please contact Elaine at eklee@medicine.ucsf.edu or 415-502-2714.

5) Orientation with Tom Gardner on dictation and UCare set-up - Please contact Tom at tomg@medicine.ucsf.edu or 415-353-1731.

6) Orientation on hospitalist clinical services – Please contact Brad Sharpe for Moffitt-Long Medical Service/CRI/CHF Hospitalist Services (sharpeb@medicine.ucsf.edu or 514-2198); Niraj Sehgal for Mt. Zion Medical Service (nirajs@medicine.ucsf.edu or 476-0723); or Quinny Cheng for Neurosurgery Co-management Service (quinny@medicine.ucsf.edu or 502-4210).

7)  STOR, UCare, and Webpacs – Your applications are being processed.  Upon set-up, please contact 415-353-2189 for STOR training; 415-514-4100 to obtain UCare login and password; and 415-502-5838 for Webpacs login and password.

8) White coat – The division will pay for your first white coat. Please send your receipt for reimbursement to Kat Li at Box 0131. If you wish, you may order from the UCSF bookstore at http://www.webmedbooks.com/ucsf/content/browse.aspx/id=115918/

9) Parking – Your application for parking is being processed.  We will let you know as soon as parking is assigned. Please note that there is currently a waitlist.

10) Keys, ID form, pager, and desk space – Please set up a time to meet Kat Li. She can be reached at 476-4854 or kli@medicine.ucsf.edu.  Best time is 8-noon as the police station accepts drop-ins for ID.  Otherwise, appointments can be made from noon-4:30.  Their phone number is 415-476-2088.

11) Clinical schedule – If you would like to confirm your clinical schedule, please contact Christine Lam at lamc@medicine.ucsf.edu or 415-885-3723.

Thank you in advance for your cooperation and understanding. We would be glad to hear your feedback on how we can improve the orientation process and make your transition smoother and easier. Welcome again!

Incubator Meetings

The mission of the Division of Hospital Medicine Incubator is to provide a collaborative environment that promotes scholarship for UCSF trainees and faculty.

 

Faculty in the UCSF Division of Hospital Medicine (DHM) pursue broad and diverse interests in teaching, quality improvement, cost reduction, patient safety, global health, palliative care, and clinical research.

The DHM Incubator is a forum where researchers, clinicians, and educators meet to provide tools and guidance necessary to promote scholarly projects across the range of our Division's activities, by connecting individuals with complementary skills and interests and providing necessary mentorship and peer support.

We define scholarship broadly, including evaluation of quality improvement, global health or other health system innovations, as well as advancements in medical education and traditional clinical research.

The Incubator welcomes a broad range of projects, including grant applications, papers, abstracts, and oral presentations, in any phase of preparation.

Questions about the Incubator should be directed to Andy Auerbach or Kirsten Kangelaris. Please contact Oralia Schatzman for questions related to the Incubator schedule.

Incubator Meetings - Materials

The Division of Hospital Medicine hosts the DHM ‘Incubator’ every Thursday from 1-2 PM in U107. The goal of the Incubator is to help develop scholarly projects among DHM faculty through a group-based ‘works in progress’ format.  Educational, quality improvement, and investigator-initiated research projects are reviewed. Questions about the Incubator should be directed to Andy Auerbach.

2010-11 Incubator Schedule:

node.Fname: About the Division of Hospital Medicine ./hospital/edel/about.html
node.FileBody:
The Division of Hospital Medicine is a national leader in clinical care, education, and research. Hospitalists care for inpatients on the general medicine service at UCSF Medical Center, as well as on the general medical consult service and the palliative care service. In addition to their clinical work, the Division of Hospital Medicine focuses on excellence in teaching, research, and systems improvement.

The Group has achieved a remarkable number of "firsts" in hospital medicine:

  • Coined the term hospitalist (in a 1996 article by Robert Wachter, MD, and Lee Goldman, MD in the New England Journal of Medicine)
  • Published the first peer-reviewed paper on hospitalists' positive impact on clinical care in JAMA
  • Hosted the first hospital medicine CME course in 1997; the course remains the nation's most popular and is now in its 10th year.
  • Edit the field's main textbook, Hospital Medicine
  • Established the nation's first hospital medicine fellowship
  • Established one of the most highly respected inpatient palliative care services in the United States, now the site of a national palliative care leadership center
  • Edit the major case-based series on End of Life care in the United States, Perspectives of Care at the Close of Life, in JAMA
  • Edit the first case-based series on medical errors ("Quality Grand Rounds" in the Annals of Internal Medicine), the popular journal on medical errors, AHRQ WebM&M and the federal medical errors portal, AHRQ Patient Safety Network, and wrote the bestselling book on medical errors, Internal Bleeding: The Truth Behind America’s Terrifying Epidemic of Medical Mistakes
  • Helped found the Society of Hospital Medicine; two of the society's first eight presidents (Drs. Wachter and Pantilat) are from the UCSF Group, and two members of the group have received the society's Young Investigator Award (Drs. Auerbach and Shojania)

Over the past few years, articles describing the program have appeared in virtually every major medical publication, along with the New York Times, the LA Times, and the Washington Post.

<html>
			<head>
			<title>UCSF Department Of Medicine  | Division of Hospital Medicine | Mt. Zion Hospital Medical Service </title>
			<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
			<LINK href="/sites/ucsfhealthhospitalmedicine.ucsf.edu/files/images/common/ucsfdom2008.css" type=text/css rel=stylesheet>
			<LINK href="/sites/ucsfhealthhospitalmedicine.ucsf.edu/files/images/common/ucsfcommon2008.css" type=text/css rel=stylesheet>

On average, approximately 2-3 new hospitalists join the UCSF Division of Hospital Medicine each year.  To be competitive for an academic position based at UCSF Medical Center (“Parnassus”), most candidates will have completed a chief residency and/or a fellowship, and have evidence of skill in teaching and leadership potential in research, quality improvement, or another academic area. 

Hospitalists also staff our non-resident service based at Mt. Zion Hospital. These faculty are fully integrated into the UCSF Division of Hospital Medicine, and have the opportunity to serve as teaching ward attendings (at UCSF Medical Center) for up to 3 months each year.  Because of their non-teaching role, their pay level is approximately 10-15% higher than the Parnassus-based academic hospitalists.  Successful candidates will be graduates of strong internal medicine residencies with tremendous clinical skills who have some academic potential and interest in teaching on the wards. 

For those entering (or interested in) a cardiology/hematology/oncology fellowship who would like to expand their inpatient cardiology/oncology experience or work in an academic environment, they may serve on two of our subspecialty hospitalist services: the Congestive Heart failure (CHF) Hospitalist Service, and the Cancer Research Institute (CRI) Hospitalist Service. The hospitalists on the CHF/CRI Service manage the day-to-day care of the patients while the cardiologists/oncologists provide the necessary specialized care. Schedule, hours, and salary are competitive.  In addition, hospitalists on our subspeciality services will have the opportunity to get involved in teaching of students and housestaff if interested. The start date for both positions is flexible.

Interested applicants should send a letter of interest, their CV, and three references to Maria Novelero, Division Administrator for Hospital Medicine, at maria@medicine.ucsf.edu. Candidates must possess an M.D. degree, be Board certified/eligible and be eligible for licensure in the State of California.  These are not J-1 Visa opportunities.

UCSF seeks candidates whose experience, teaching, research, or community service has prepared them to contribute to our commitment to diversity and excellence. UCSF is an Equal Opportunity/Affirmative Action Employer. The University undertakes affirmative action to assure equal employment opportunity for underutilized minorities and women, for persons with disabilities, and for covered veterans.  All qualified applicants are encouraged to apply, including minorities and women.

Highest Quality in Inpatient Care, Excellence in Education & Academic Leadership: Our Commitment, Our Passion

The UCSF Division of Hospital Medicine has achieved a remarkable number of "firsts" in hospital medicine: coined the term hospitalist, published the first peer-reviewed paper on hospitalists' positive impact on clinical care in JAMA, hosted the first hospital medicine CME course in 1997 and the first Hospitalist Mini-College in 2008, among others. The Division of Hospital Medicine is a national leader in clinical care, education, and research. Hospitalists care for inpatients on the general medicine service at UCSF Medical Center, as well as on the general medical consult service and the palliative care service. The UCSF Division of Hospital Medicine has achieved a remarkable number of "firsts" in hospital medicine: coined the term hospitalist, published the first peer-reviewed paper on hospitalists' positive impact on clinical care in JAMA, hosted the first hospital medicine CME course in 1997 and the first Hospitalist Mini-College in 2008, among others. The UCSF Division of Hospital Medicine has achieved a remarkable number of "firsts" in hospital medicine: coined the term hospitalist, published the first peer-reviewed paper on hospitalists' positive impact on efficiency and quality, hosted the first hospital medicine CME course, and the first Hospitalist Mini-College, launched the first hospital medicine fellowship, among others. Our commitment is to provide the highest quality inpatient care, excel as educators, and be academic leaders in hospital medicine.

1. To provide the highest quality inpatient care, and to do so efficiently
  2. To redefine and improve the standard of inpatient care
  3. To excel as educators in conveying the principles of evidence based inpatient medicine to students, residents, colleagues, and patients, and transmitting the excitement, gratification, and humanism of hospital medicine
  4. To remain academic leaders in hospital medicine, helping bring new knowledge and insight into quality improvement, patient safety, end of life care, evidence-based medicine, and clinical research

A Conversation with Adeena Khan | See previous interviews

Adeena Khan
Assistant Clinical Professor

Where were you born and raised?

I was born in Pakistan and spent much of my early childhood there. I came to the US when at age 6 and have wonderful memories of being there. One of the great things about having opportunities to return every couple of years while growing up in the US is to see how much Western culture influences Pakistani culture and vice versa. I still recall walking into a McDonalds in Pakistan and ordering a chicken tikka burger, or at Pizza Hut, the spicy masala pizza. My culture has continued to be a big part of my life. At school fashion shows, I'd proudly wear traditional salwar kameez and now I have friends comment that they love wearing similar tunic-style garments that remind them of my salwar kameezes. It has been fun to see that exchange of East and West!

Where my dad comes from, there might not be electricity or cell phone reception and you can't always log on to WiFi, but I think of it as a luxury, to be able to disconnect for some time and enjoy the simplicity of life. I have two brothers, one of whom is a consultant and a younger brother who is a grad student at Northwest. My parents are in Seattle so a weekend visit with my folks is easy.

What sounds and scents best elicit memories of where you were born and raised?

My favorite foods are anything spicy. I can still remember a small cart in my dad's town that sold samosas, an aroma that causes me to completely melt down! It's such a warm feeling that reminds me of home and of my grandmother, because they were her favorite food and she was a fun, spicy person. Certain foods define home and warmth. I remember, too, the sounds of street vendors selling at 7 AM; they are called rari-wallahs, and each has a different singsong to sell their wares, onions or tomatoes or other foods. Those sounds define city life in Pakistan.

How many languages do you think in? Are there times that you wish important concepts in your language translated better into English?

I think in two languages. When I am thinking about things academic or work-related, I think in English but, when I am thinking spiritually or emotionally, I think in Urdu. I find myself switching back and forth fairly comfortably, just like our consciousness does. With people who are close to me, I have been known to speak to them in Urdu regardless that they might not understand! When I first immigrated to this country, the difference in communicating respect was difficult because there is no difference in personal address between people; in English, there is just "you," but, in Urdu, there is a difference in how you address a child or an elder. I feel that, in Urdu, that aspect of showing respect for a person, or someone who's older, might come through differently. In our culture, a woman older than you is called, "Auntie," but that doesn't translate into English without some confusion.

How different or similar are you to your grandmother? In features or in traits?

My maternal grandmother was a quiet soul, very innocent and giving. She would give away money, food, or gifts that she'd been given, to anyone who needed it and, even after she was diagnosed with Alzheimer's, the joy of giving, of sharing with others, was so engrained that she kept giving to the poor long into the progression of the disease, and it was very beautiful to watch. My mother tried to instill that same quality in us, to help us realize that joy comes from sharing with others. My paternal grandmother was a very feisty and fun woman, a confident and outspoken matriarch of five brothers and three sisters. She helped run an orphanage with my grandfather and cooked, handled the finances, and was very purpose-driven. My mom says that I am much more like her.

What is the best road trip music that makes you happy while you drive? And do you sing along?

I love, definitely love, Bollywood from the 80s and 90s! They have fun, dance- and sing-along music. I have no shame in admitting it and will sing along to old-school music that's catchy and fun.

What is absolutely irresistible to your sweet tooth and when do you indulge?

Oh, my goodness! I love ice cream in any shape or formit's absolutely wonderful and it brings me back to bike-riding and ice cream days as a child. My husband introduced me to salted caramel from Bi-Rite but my other favorite is the mango ice cream at Mitchell'sso yummy and amazing. I take my parents every time they visit and they always say that it is just like back home.

Can you describe the beauty of hijab? What have you found that people may not understand about it?

I started wearing hijab when I was in college; it was a personal decision and not the easiest. There are so many beautiful lessons I've learned by wearing it over the past few years. One thing that people do not always understand about the hijab is that it is the choice for a woman to wear it, and one form of worship. I think it's a strong depiction of identity and it signifies a strong-willed, feminine, and feminist woman. As soon as you enter a room, you are identified as a Muslim woman, and it shows that you are not afraid to show what you believe in. I think it adds to a more nurturing part of my personality and, to me, it's been an amazing experience both on a personal level and in connecting with others. I was drawn to it for spiritual and religious reasons but I have come to love it as a part of me for so many other reasons!

You were recently married, congratulations! Can you recall a touching image of your celebration that you will forever treasure?

We were married in October, not the warmest time of year in Seattle! I recall being very nervous about our photography shoot. It was cold and windy, my dupatta and jewelry were heavy and my mind was preoccupied with details like the food and decorations, and my husband just kept telling jokes and making me laugh. It made time stand still, the cold go away, and the photographer captured it all beautifully.

Do you feel that work is play or that play is work?

I love what I do so work is play. This is my second year on faculty and it's been amazing. I learn new things every single day, discovering both weaknesses and strengths in myself. I think play is playI love being outdoors and hiking, and spending time with family and friendsthere's not enough time in a lifetime to enjoy those moments.

Are you a lover of words, of poetry? What literature do you find compelling and what was your last best read?

I definitely love literature and wish I had more time to read. The last book I read was "And the Mountain Echoed" by Khaled Hosseini. There is a spiritual gathering that I attending on Sunday evenings, and much of the poetry and songs are many centuries old. On those evenings, I turn my phone off, close my eyes, and really enjoy the experience.

What was your biggest worry five years ago? Five hours ago?

I recall being in awe of my residents and attendings, their immense knowledge, bedside manner, and clinical skills were so impressive while I was learning to check off boxes as an intern five years ago. I worried about how I would develop as a physician, and if I would be able to follow in the footsteps of these incredible role models. Five hours ago, I worried about how I would get teaching in for my ward team that has been working so hard.

Thank you, Adeena.
- by Oralia Schatzman

A Conversation with Adrienne Green | See previous interviews

Adrienne Green
 Associate Chief Medical Officer

How do you maintain focus with so many obligations and how do you channel your energies?

Focusing energies has everything to do with prioritization, deciding what is the most pressing thing I must do today, whether family or work-related. Things that are low priority sometimes have to wait so that I can get the things done that are most important. I have a hybrid electronic and paper system for managing my to-do’s but the things that are at the top are usually just in my head.

Do you have a green thumb? What are your favorite flowers?

I would say I have a light green thumb. I have an amazing north-facing kitchen window where orchids grow well. I love to plant bulbs in the fall so that I can cut freesia in the spring and have them sitting on my kitchen table. Freesia and sweet peas are my favorites.

Who makes you laugh?

My kids make me laugh. They are always coming up with things that are surprising, funny, and witty. While leaving a friend’s home recently, one of my boys hid and then jumped out and scared everybody. We were all in stitches because it was totally uncharacteristic for him. I loved it.

Which book is an old companion and why? Is there an author you particularly like now?

There are so many books! There isn’t a particular one that I have read and re-read. My recent favorites are The Invisible Bridge, Paris Wife, and Loving Frank. For escapism, I enjoy the Nesbø series. I just read Katie Hafner’s new book, and it was very well written and touching.

Where were your grandparents from? Do you recall hearing stories about how they lived?

Three grandparents were from Poland and one was from Russia. My dad’s dad escaped from the Polish army during World War I by cutting holes in his shoes so that he would be injured or get frostbite. He was sent to an infirmary and escaped from there. He was one of the youngest of 11 kids and contacted an older sister who lived in New York. She regularly sent him money thinking that he was saving the money to come to America. But he thought that she was married to a wealthy banker and instead used the funds to travel the world. When he finally arrived in America, he found this huge extended family living in a tiny tenement apartment on the Lower East Side.

What music do you love and what can you not stand?

I really can’t stand the rap that my kids love. It makes car rides a little stressful. From a music perspective, I am stuck in the 70s and 80s, happy with pop and rock.

Do you take after either parent? Are you very different or are there traits that you share?

I have bits and pieces of both of my parents’ traits. Both were detail-oriented, hardworking, and studious types. My mom was totally a shopper and clotheshorse; she was always well put together. I definitely do not take after her in those ways. In other realms, my whole family loves to read, cook and eat good food together, and spend time exploring the outdoors.

What is a family favorite dish that you prepare? Is it one you inherited or made up?

I inherited tried and true recipes like lasagna and my maternal grandmother’s matzo ball soup and her lemon bars. We’re still making them and my kids love them as much as my parents and I did.

Does the neighborhood in which you live evoke memories of where you grew up?

No, it is completely different. I grew up on a hill in Portland with a tiny cul-de-sac where there were three houses. Although it was in Portland proper, we were in the middle of a forest so we could venture around the forest and sled down the hills when it snowed. We love our SF neighborhood but it is totally different than Portland.

Are your last thoughts as you retire, pragmatic or do they wander?

My thoughts wander and I’ve become a Scramble With Friends addict at bedtime because it is such a complete escape, and I read a lot for the same reason.

Thank you, Adrienne.
- by Oralia Schatzman
