April 2010

 

Patrick Kneeland, the residents of the Health Systems and Leadership Track, and the Pathways leadership won the WGEA’s best GME poster award for their poster “A Potent Partnership:  Empowering Residents to Lead a Failure-Modes-and-Effects Analysis for Academic Medical Center." About 15 IM residents did a terrific job analyzing our anticoagulation process, determining its vulnerabilities, and effectively presenting their findings to high level UCSFMC committees. Their work was submitted to the Joint Commission as the institutional FMEA, and the educational outcomes including knowledge acquisition and behavior change were impressive.

Cindy Lai received the PISCES School Teaching Award from the third-year PISCES medical students and the Class of 2010 Graduation Teaching Award from the fourth-year medical students.

BJ Miller is the recipient of the Osler Teaching Award.

Som Mookherjee has been accepted to the Teaching Scholars Program for 2010-2011.

Stephanie Rennke, Cindy Lai, and Brad Sharpe were nominated for the 2010 Kaiser Awards for Excellence in Teaching Award.

Bob Wachter makes #10 in the Most Powerful Physician Executives of 2010.

Michelle Mourad is the recipient of the AME Cooke Award for the Scholarship of Teaching and Learning.

Kirsten Kangelaris is the recipient of this year's SHM Young Researcher Award. The award will be presented at SHM after the "Best of Research, Innovations and Clinical Vignettes" presentations. In addition to the glory, the award comes with research support.

Margaret Fang received SHM Excellence in Research Award.

Patrick Kneeland won the SHM Clinical Vignette Award for “A Case of Skin Ulcers and Neutropenia: Definitely Not a Helminth Problem.”


March 2010

 

Quinn Cheng was selected by the Department of Medicine as one of its three "Master Clinicians" this year. A singular, and well deserved honor.

Steve Pantilat was selected as a finalist for the Irvine Foundation award, one of only 11 finalists out of 300 nominees. This is a huge achievement, and it is accompanied by a $25,000 award to the palliative care program to support its crucial work.

Bob Wachter has been selected as one of three inaugural "Masters" of the Society of Hospital Medicine.

The Patient Satisfaction Committee recognizes Heather Whelan and Stephanie Rennke for their exemplary roles in delivering patient-centered care. Heather is noted particularly for her consistent strong communication with specialty teams, particularly Interventional Radiology. And Stephanie is recognized for always going the extra mile for her patients and being a remarkably caring patient advocate.


February 2010

 

Niraj Sehgal and our multidisciplinary rounds are featured in ACP Hospitalist. See what he has to say about daily face-to-face meetings and how they improve outcomes and teamwork.

Congrats to Andy Auerbach, who recently was notified that he will be awarded a K24 Career Development Award from the National Heart Lung and Blood Institute -- a fantastic development. This not only helps support Andy's research, but his many mentoring activities.

Congrats as well to Margaret Fang, who received this year's Society of Hospital Medicine Outstanding Researcher award at the national meeting next month. This honors the top researcher in the nation in our field.

Rupa Marya is featured in ACP Hospitalist Issue this month, check out the story on her.


January 2010

 

Anna Abramson has been awarded a grant for her project, "Universal HIV Screening Pilot in Mount Zion Medicine Wards" from Mt. Zion Health Fund. Congrats!

Sri Shamasunder has been asked by Partners in Health to help out with their effort in Haiti -- he'll work with a group of medical professionals at Haiti's national hospital, which is presently caring for about 1500 wounded people, many of whom are awaiting surgery.

Lindsay Mazotti writes a thought-provoking article in JAMA on maintaining integrity as a physician.


December 2009

 

Don't miss a Q&A with Bob Wachter featured in New York Times.

Steve Pantilat moderated a panel at the Commonwealth Club of California. Watch the video.

Congrats to Andrew Auerbach for being awarded a highly competitive K24 award (on his first submission -- very rare). Per Andy, "this K24 is particularly enjoyable as it will allow me to mentor faculty with an interest in comparative effectiveness/implementation research in cardiopulmonary diseases."

 

November 2009

 

You knew he was a top hospitalist, but now it is official. Congratulations to Brad Sharpe -- very well deserved.

Neil Gupta comments about discharge improvement in The Hospitalist.

 

October 2009

 

The Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality has asks DHM faculty and staff to continue to produce AHRQ WebM&M and AHRQ PSNet for the next 5 years, in a contract worth approximately $10 million

Congratulations to Andrew Auerbach who was just named the Western Society of Clinical Investigation's 2010 Outstanding Investigator of the Year

 

September 2009

 

Brad Sharpe received Excellence in Teaching Award from Academy of Medical Educators

Niraj Sehgal has been selected for membership in The Haile T. Debas Academy of Medical Educators

 

August 2009

 

Sri Shamasunder's experience volunteering in Burundi is featured in this ServiceSpace blog.

Tune into KGO radio for Steven Pantilat's discussion on Palliative Care, death panels and related ideas and topics

 

July 2009

 

Karen Hauer has been elected as the president of Clerkship Directors in Internal Medicine

 

June 2009

 

Sumana Kesh and Stephanie Rennke have been awarded a grant for their project, "Designing a Mt. Zion Discharge Program – Discharge Facilitator and Care Transitions System Utilizing an Interdisciplinary Team Approach" from Mt. Zion Health Fund

Elizabeth Murphy has been awarded a grant from Mt. Zion Health Fund for her project, “Proactive Geriatric Care Unit (PGCU)”

Liz Goldman has been awarded a K08 grant for her project, "Evaluating Present-On-Admission for Performance Reporting" from AHRQ

Congratulations to Aparajita Singh who has been accepted into the UCSF GI fellowship starting in July 2010

Margaret Fang's project, "Literacy, Numeracy, and Risk Perception Among People Taking Warfarin," has been awarded funding from the Clinical and Translational Science Institute's Strategic Opportunities Support Program

Liz Goldman has been awarded a REAC grant for her project, "Evaluating Present-On-Admission for Performance Reporting"

 

May 2009

 

Stephanie Rennke has been awarded by Instructional Grants Program for her project, "Designing an Interactive Curriculum for Third-Year Medical, Pharmacy and Nursing Students on Inpatient Geriatric Issues and Safe Transitions in Care"

Rupa Marya enriches the cultural landscape of San Francisco through her band, Rupa and The April Fishes. Read their terrific review on American Chronicle.


Bob Wachter was chosen one of the most powerful physician-executives in 2009 by the readers of Modern Healthcare and Modern Physician. Congratulations! Read more about it.

 

April 2009

 

Stephanie Rennke and Heather Nye are two of 14 UCSF faculty accepted into the UCSF Teaching Scholars Program. Congratulations!

Listen to Steven Pantilat's appearance on KQED radio this week, discussing the role of faith in the doctor-patient relationship

Russ Cucina is featured in the New York Times for his roles in medicine and technology. Read the article here.

Niraj Sehgal will serve as the Department of Medicine's first Associate Chair for Quality Improvement & Patient Safety.

Congratulations to Karen Hauer who just received a renewal of her endowed chair

 

February 2009

 

UCSF Division of Hospital Medicine has been selected as a participating site for SHM's Project Boost

 

December 2008

 

The first Hospitalist Mini College was a success! See The Hospitalist December 2008 issue

Brad Sharpe has been appointed Associate Program Director for Inpatient Affairs in the residency training

 

October 2007

 

Bob Wachter launches second book and blog on Health Care Quality

Palliative Care Service named one of the top three programs nationwide on Circle of Life

 

September 2005

 

Margaret Fang's study shows that women with atrial fibrillation have higher risk of stroke than men

 

May 2005

 

Adrienne Green was one of the 4 recipients of the 2005 Exceptional Physician Awards

 

May 2004

 

Hospitalists Have a Positive Impact on End-of-life Care

Even in the middle of big city you can find lots of nature parks to escape the hustle and bustle of city life.

Golden Gate Park: http://www.sftravel.com/ggpark.html

San Francisco Botanical Gardens: http://www.sfbotanicalgarden.org/

San Francisco Conservatory of Flowers: http://www.conservatoryofflowers.org/

Stow Lake: http://www.yelp.com/biz/stow-lake-boat-and-bike-rentals-san-francisco

Buena Vista Park: http://www.sfnpc.org/buenavistaparkhistory

Twin Peaks: http://www.sftravel.com/twinpeakssanfrancisco.html

Japanese Tea Gardens: http://japaneseteagardensf.com/

Shakespeare Garden: http://www.yelp.com/biz/shakespeare-garden-san-francisco

Maritime National Park: http://www.nps.gov/safr/

Find out which parks are dog-friendly here: http://www.sfdogparks.com/

San Francisco is encased by the gorgeous Pacific Ocean and the stunning Bay. There are many interesting beaches and shore-side activities, from Alcatraz to windsurfing.

Ocean Beach: http://www.parksconservancy.org/visit/park-sites/ocean-beach.html

Baker Beach: http://www.parksconservancy.org/visit/park-sites/baker-beach.html

Alcatraz: http://www.alcatrazcruises.com/

Sutro Baths: http://www.sutrobaths.com/

San Francisco Bay: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Bay_Area

Why San Francisco?

San Francisco is known for its array of dining  choices, cultural landmarks, and progressive thinking. Life in the city is  truly diverse, with each neighborhood boasting of its own microcosm of foods,  styles, and activities. There is so much to San Francisco that at times it can feel  overwhelming - in a very positive way. Here is a guide to some of our favorite things to do, eat, and  see in San Francisco.

node.Fname: Facts about SHM and Project BOOST ./hospital/home/shmboost.html
node.FileBody:
Facts about SHM and Project BOOST

The Society of Hospital Medicine (SHM)

Mission:
SHM is dedicated to promoting the highest quality care for all hospitalized patients. SHM is committed to promoting excellence in the practice of hospital medicine through education, advocacy and research.

Membership:
Approximately 8,000 members, as of December 2008. Membership is open to physicians
in training and in practice, healthcare administrators, healthcare analysts, and others
interested in hospital medicine.

General Information:

  • Provides continuing education and industry updates for hospitalists through a monthly publication, The Hospitalist and publishes the nation’s first and only peer-reviewed journal for hospital medicine, the Journal of Hospital Medicine
  • Conducts surveys, prepares written analyses and conducts discussion forums that define the specialty of hospital medicine
  • Develops policy and position statements that address the concerns and issues of hospitalists
  • Advocates on behalf of hospitalists before other medical societies and government and regulatory agencies
  • Holds the largest annual conference for the hospital medicine specialty. SHM’s annual meeting, Hospital Medicine 2009, will be held May 14-17 in Chicago, IL.

For more information about SHM please visit www.hospitalmedicine.org or call 1-800-843-3360.

Project BOOST (Better Outcomes for Older adults through Safe Transitions)

Project Goal:
Improve the care of patients as they transition from the hospital to home.

OUTCOMES:
By improving discharge processes, Project BOOST aims to:

  • Reduce 30-day readmission rates for general medicine patients (with particular focus on older adults)
  • Improve facility patient satisfaction scores
  • Improve the institution’s H-CAHPS scores related to discharge
  • Improve flow of information between hospital and outpatient physicians
  • Ensure high-risk patients are identified and specific interventions are offered to mitigate their risk
  • Improve patient and family education practices to encourage use of the teach-back process around risk specific issues.

 

Project BOOST Mentoring Program consists of:

  • An invitation to participate in a the Project BOOST Quality Improvement Skills Course, a  2 day training conference
  • A year of mentoring provided via teleconferencing and e-mails to tailor the toolkit to the needs of the institution, implementation of tools and evaluation of the program’s impact. 
  • Evaluation tools, including run charts
  • Project management tools
  • Access to networking opportunities to share successes and challenges with peer sites

Sponsorship and Development
Project BOOST is funded by the John A. Hartford Foundation and has been developed by SHM in conjunction with a national advisory board of recognized leaders in hospital medicine, care transitions, payers and regulatory agencies. The board includes representatives from the Agency for Healthcare Research Quality (AHRQ), The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS), The Joint Commission, Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, the Society of Hospital Medicine (SHM), Institute for Healthcare Improvement (IHI), among others.

For more information about Project BOOST please contact Lauren Valentino at 267-702-2672 or email BOOST@hospitalmedicine.org.

Shop

There are as many shopping opportunities in San Francisco as sight-seeing attractions. Each neighborhood has its own niche shops and boutiques. And of course, there are great shopping districts for every kind of taste.

Case Review

Introduction to the Case Review Process

Purpose:

The goal of our case review process is to improve quality and safety by learning from past performance, errors, and near misses, and to gain awareness of areas of vulnerability in our practice, so that we might improve these areas;  thereby creating a safer environment for the delivery of patient care.

The Committee:

The Hospital Medicine Quality and Safety Case Review Committee is composed of various leaders in hospital medicine, other hospitalist faculty, fellows, chief residents and rotating housestaff on Quality elective. The committee meets monthly to discuss cases as a group. Committee members act as liaisons to other parts of the hospital environment for gathering more information as well as initiating improvements in our systems of care. Committee members also serve to mentor housestaff in case review and understanding systems analysis and improvement.

The Cases:

Cases are referred from many sources including: physician providers, incident reports, hospital committees, other clinical services and patient grievances.

Case Actions:

Cases result in many different types of actions with the overarching goal of improving our practice and systems of care. These actions include: education (ie. housestaff conferences), creation of task forces/working groups, changes to order forms, IT solutions, changes in processes, inter-service meetings to resolve problems, dissemination of guidelines, etc. Read the case review learnings now.

Confidentiality:

The case review process is confidential under the umbrella of quality review, and allows for open discussion of events and improvement of our care in a venue that is protected from medical legal review.

New On-Line Tool to Refer Cases:

https://medstaff.ucsfmedicalcenter.org/eoppe/mnm/

DeSTRESS Patients: Decrease Inappropriate Stress Ulcer Prophylaxis

Medication Overuse Collaborative: ICU Stress Ulcer Prophylaxis Project

Background:
  • Overuse and inappropriate use of pharmacologic acid-suppressive therapy to prevent stress ulcer-related bleeding
  • Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs)
  • Histamine-2 receptor antagonists (H2RAs)
  • Sucralfate
  • Risks of SUP: pneumonia, gastrointestinal infections, fractures of hip, wrist, and spine per FDA post-marketing surveillance data, adverse drug events
  • Costly

Objectives:

  • To develop targeted and evidence-based UCSF guidelines on use of SUP
  • To develop and implement a pharmacist-led intervention to reduce inappropriate SUP in the ICUs

Project Timeline
  • Collect baseline data (post-APEX)
  • Evaluate data on SUP use on ICU discharge
  • Develop and implement pharmacist-led intervention
  • Reminders on admission and discharge from ICU
  • Education and awareness initiative for prescribers
  • ICU and service champions
  • Culture change
  • Achieve goals
  • Establish and approve guidelines for SUP at UCSF
  • Reduce inappropriate SUP use and cost
  • Successfully implement and sustain the intervention

Enhancing Care Transitions

The Division of Hospital Medicine has identified the discharge process as a key priority area for our quality improvement efforts in the 2009-2010 calendar years. Under the leadership of Neil Gupta, MD, and Maria Novelero, MA, MPA, the division is embarking on a complete overhaul of the discharge process, with focused attention on patients on the medicine service at both the Parnassus and Mt. Zion campuses.

The Division of Hospital Medicine has been selected as one of 24 hospitals across the country to participate in the Society of Hospital Medicine's ‘BOOST’ (Better Outcomes for Older adults through Safe Transitions) collaborative. Through our involvement in BOOST, the division will be working to accomplish the following goals:

1. Identify patients at high risk for readmission or complications after discharge by using a BOOST-validated screening tool
2. Improve communication between the inpatient team and primary care provider
3. Improve patient education (including knowledge of diagnoses, medications, and follow-up care plan) at the time of discharge
4. Develop a method for enhanced communication between patients and health care providers immediately after discharge

For more information, visit our intranet site. Please note it is available for internal UCSF faculty and staff

Case Review Learnings

“What happens when a DNR/DNI patient has cardiopulmonary arrest and the goldenrod has not been signed by an attending in 24 hours?”

Problem: Unsigned goldenrods become invalid after 24 hours, and the code team is supposed to code the patient.  In addition, if step 3 on the form is not filled out, even if the attending signs, the order is similarly invalid.

Scope of the Problem:

  • Based on interviews with nightfloats, they renew expired orders as a “workaround” up to 2x/night. Some interns make duplicate goldenrods in order to bring one to the attending and leave one in the chart.
  • According to the code blue committee, this is an even greater problem on services other than medicine, though we tend to address code status with every patient yielding a very high rate of goldenrods.
  • Workarounds create unnecessary inefficiency in the system, taking away from other tasks that add value to patient care and education.
  • Code teams have had to start and stop codes, due to lack of clarity about incomplete goldenrod orders, and disagreement among those present regarding what should be done.
  • For attendings, it is easy to see how this signature can be missed.
    • Going to physical chart is outside of typical workflow for attendings.
    • The attending may not have had time to discuss code status with the patient or surrogate.
    • Attendings are max’d on post call days with boluses of acute patients, and skeleton dayfloat team.
    • Charts may not be on the floor when attending is on the floor, etc.
    • Patients getting transferred from surgery require rewritten goldenrods (as clarification, transfers in level of care do not).
  • Nonetheless, we would like to perform better as a service, decrease workarounds and make sure code teams aren’t put in the position of having to code people who don’t want to be coded.

System Solutions attempted so far

  1. IT fix: consideration of a change in the system by which goldenrod orders are entered (to electronic order)-Off the table now because Epic is coming.
  2. Education: announcements at faculty meetings x 3 to raise awareness.
  3. Reminders to attendings:
    1. RNs on 14 remind attendings at multidisciplinary rounds.
    2. RNs are encouraged to page attendings directly when an order is pending.

Next steps:

  • Epic order entry will probably be the next major system change to help with this problem, currently leaving each individual accountable for incorporating this paper signature into their workflow.
  • For now, use personal reminder systems (like checklists).
  • System of audit and feedback: information regarding expired goldenrods will be tracked and you will get feedback about your own performance.
  • Following a couple months of audit and feedback, faculty will get calls directly for signature rather than going through nightfloat.

High Value Care Committee

Mission

Team

Projects

High Utilizer Committee:

It is widely known that a small percentage of patients account for an outsized share of healthcare cost. A similar phenomenon exists for emergency room visits and hospital readmissions - a small group of patients account for an outsized number of visits each year. While complex medical and psychosocial factors undoubtedly play a role in this phenomenon, physicians must also examine how health systems could serve these patients more effectively.

Inspired by work from John Nelson at Overlake Hospital Medical Center in Washington State, our Division formed a High-Utilizer Committee to design care plans for patients with high use of ER and inpatient services. The goals of the project are as follow:

  • Improve patient care by avoiding unnecessary or inappropriate diagnostic or therapeutic interventions by physicians unfamiliar with the patient
  • Improve patient satisfaction by bringing consistency to a patient's care (i.e. avoid "reinventing the wheel" each time a patient is seen)
  • Decrease ER visits and hospital readmissions by more effectively linking inpatient care to outpatient care plans and outpatient resources
  • Improve provider satisfaction by providing clear guidance and rules for a patient's care

  • The Committee is multi-disciplinary and includes representatives from nursing, psychiatry, social work, emergency medicine, and hospital medicine. All care plans will also include input from the patient's primary care physician
  • Care plans will cover key elements of an encounter, including ER care, admission criteria, inpatient care plan, discharge criteria, and transition to outpatient care
  • Harness the EMR to put care plans in a location clearly visible to all providers who see the patient
  • Re-evaluate care plans at regular intervals to keep them up-to-date

Data Dashboard:

Audit and feedback of data is a critical component of any quality improvement (QI) endeavor. However, at many institutions, the process for performing audit and feedback to inpatient clinicians does not provide data that is sufficiently accurate, timely, and actionable to make it effective for driving change.

In the Division of Hospital Medicine, a pioneering group of physicians and data scientists have developed a QI Data Dashboard that fulfills these important criteria.

  • Accurate: the addition of metrics to the dashboard is moderated by a governance committee that scrutinizes the data to make sure it is accurate and reflects a valid measurement for the process or outcome under consideration.
  • Timely: data is automatically pulled from the electronic medical record (EMR) every day. It is then filtered and visualized in real-time by a system that was developed in-house.
  • Actionable: since the unit of care delivery on the wards is the ward team (attending, resident, interns, and students), the Data Dashboard performs QI metric attribution by team. The visualization software allows ward teams to pull up their team-level data and dive deeper into certain metrics to understand their practice patterns in more detail. Teams can even use links to the patient's chart in the software so they can write orders to correct their deficiencies in real-time.

Rather than simply roll out this software tool to the entire Division, the leadership of the program decided to study it in a randomized controlled trial. The Data Trial splits the ward teams at UCSF into two groups. One group meets briefly each week with a physician or data scientist coach to go over their dashboard results and discuss ways to improve. The other group is usual practice and does not receive access to the data or weekly coaching. Results from the trial will be published later this year.

Team Members: Alvin Rajkomar, Victoria Valencia, Sumant Ranji, Michelle Mourad, and Sajan Patel

Promoting Sleep Project:

If you or your loved one has spent a night in a hospital, you know firsthand how challenging it can be to get a good night's sleep. Whether it is fluorescent lighting, the noise or the constant interruptions due to medication administration, vitals, or blood draws, we often hear about these common disruptors of sleep from our patients. While few studies specifically link sleep and patient outcomes, most physicians agree that the connection is obvious:

"Patients need sleep. If they get more of it, they'll likely recover faster."

In addition, the "quietness of the hospital environment" is a patient experience question in the nationally administered HCAHPS survey, so health systems have a keen interest in tackling this important issue from the perspective of value-based purchasing.

The good news is there are several low-hanging fruit solutions that we are implementing at our institution to promote sleep and an optimal healing environment for our patients. Interventions include:

  • Modifying the admission order set to allow reduced nighttime vital sign checks.
  • Creating a view in the electronic medical record of all interventions (including lab checks, respiratory treatments, and vital signs) that might awaken a patient at night in order to identify discontinuation opportunities.
  • Developing a bedtime checklist for nurses and patient care assistants to assess patients for sleep readiness in the hospital, including turning off the TV and lights and providing ear plugs if necessary.

Team Members: Michelle Mourad, Sasha Morduchowicz, Timothy Judson, and Dan Hausrath

High Value Care Committee

Our Goal:
To create a framework for identifying, designing, and promoting projects specifically aimed at improving healthcare value at a large academic medical center

Our Mission:
To raise cost awareness, reduce unnecessary resource utilization, increase efficiency and patient throughput, and create stewards of high value, responsible health care in the Division of Hospital Medicine at UCSF.

Our Vision:
To be national leaders and exemplers in the delivery of high-value patient care.

Improving Discharge Process

As a member of the Society of Hospital Medicine's ‘BOOST’ (Better Outcomes for Older adults through Safe Transitions), the Divsion of Hospital Medicine continues in it’s efforts to improve the discharge process with the goal of improving patients quality of care are reducing unnecessary readmissions. Michelle Mourad, MD and Ellen Kynoch, RN lead a multidisciplinary team of physicians, nurses, pharmacists, case managers and social workers invested in changing the way patients are prepared for discharge.

Our efforts have included:

1. Implementing teachback on our medicine floors
2. Creating patient centered discharge documentation
3. Setting physician expectations for multidisciplinary rounds
4. Implementing a timely and relevant electronic discharge summary to be completed on the day of discharge
5. Creating a post-discharge hotline for patients and their families to call after discharge
6. Implementing a 72 hour follow-up phone call program to troubleshoot post-discharge issues

    

*The link to "Meetings and Progress Updates" is only accessible by DHM members and other UCSF staff involved in the discharge improvement project. Please log in with your email login and password. If you need access, please contact Kat Li.

The UCSF Division of Hospital Medicine is dedicated to providing the highest quality inpatient care for patients on the UCSF Medical Service and to the promotion of quality improvement and patient safety throughout the medical center. Under the direction Cat Lau, the Quality and Safety Program aims to develop data-driven strategies to improve care and to lead the field by disseminating our experiences locally and nationally.

Strategic planning and discussion of innovative new projects takes place at the monthly Value Improvement Committee meeting. Since QI projects require accurate clinical data to drive interventions and provide audit and feedback, the Division has an in-house data acquisition and validation team to provide data from our EMR directly to hospitalists. Clinical-facing projects nearly always require a multidisciplinary team for implementation, including nurses, case managers, and social workers. The unit-based leadership team for the hospital's primary Medicine floors is the next stop to implementing a quality improvement project. Finally, the monthly QI Lunch brings all the faculty together to hear about new projects, brainstorm and troubleshoot trouble areas, and celebrate the success of our colleagues. Projects that bridge the inpatient and outpatient settings are well-served by the Office of Population Health, which manages our accountable care organization.

Our Division is vigilant about patient safety and has a robust infrastructure for reporting and investigating near misses or adverse events. We are proud that these cases are often brought to light by our Medicine residents. The Case Review Committee pairs small groups of residents (on their Procedures, Quality, and Safety elective) with a faculty member as they perform chart review and interviews to investigate patient safety issues. They present their findings at our monthly Case Review meeting where we develop system changes to prevent future events.

With their diverse interests and backgrounds, members of the group are currently leading a variety of innovative projects. Follow this link to read more about a few highlighted projects.

UCSF hospitalists are also leaders and key participants in many interdisciplinary medical center performance improvement committees including the Patient Safety Committee, Clinical Performance Improvement Committee, Physicians Advisory Group for Clinical Information Systems, Pharmacy and Therapeutics Committee, and the Patient Flow Committee. Both the CMO and CMIO of UCSF Health are hospitalists, as is the leader of the UCSF Accountable Care Organization.

Case Review Learnings

This section will feature deidentified cases, learnings and quality improvement initiatives that we hope will help you next time you are on service. Relevant materials will remain on the website as a reference to you. We encourage everyone to review these, as this will also be a method of disseminating important case review related information to you.

  • Tests pending at discharge
  • Hospitalist contact information for non-acute care providers
  • Point of contact for questions
  • Post discharge follow-up phone calls

Improving Discharge Process

PCP Communication

  • Build PCP database
  • Standardize communication at admission and discharge
  • Communicate essential information to outpatient providers
  • Fax/ email important notes to PCP
  • Completion of discharge summary

Improving Discharge Process

Patient Education

  • Medication education
  • Medication reconciliation
  • Health education pamphlets
  • Patient centered teach-back education
  • Knowledge of diagnoses, treating physicians, outpatient follow-up plan

Improving Discharge Process

Risk Assessment: The 8 “P’s”

  • Problem Medications
       Anticoagulants, Insulin, Cardiac Meds, Narcotics
  • Psychiatric Diagnosis
  • Principal Diagnosis
       Cancer, Stroke, DM, COPD, Heart Failure
  • Primary MD
  • Poor Adherence
  • Polypharmacy
  • Patient Support
  • Prior Hospitalizations

Enhancing Care Transitions

UCSF Transitional Discharge Clinic: A Pilot Program

Recognizing the importance of timely follow-up after hospitalization, the medical service established a position for a discharge coordinator who is responsible for scheduling follow-up appointments. Housestaff and faculty on the general medical and cardiology services who request follow-up appointments can do so via our electronic note writing system. Our discharge coordinator will receive these requests, process referrals and schedule appointments. Once an appointment is scheduled, the primary team will be notified and the appointment information will be included in the discharge paperwork. If the appointment is scheduled after the patient has left the hospital, our discharge coordinator will call the patient at home with the appointment information.

Improving Discharge Process

Impact of an Integrated Electronic Discharge Document

Hospital discharge summaries communicate information necessary for ongoing patient care in the outpatient setting. Despite regulations by JCAHO and CMS discharge summaries frequently lack critical information about patients’ hospital stay and are often delayed long past the time of discharge. Once dictated, discharge summaries often fail to reach outpatient providers. To address these concerns, we propose to create an electronic hospital discharge summary completed in a standardized form that interfaces with the hospital Electronic Medical Record (EMR), UCare. Read how it works.

Improving Discharge Process

Interdisciplinary Rounds

Interdisciplinary rounds are held daily Monday through Friday on the general medical unit. During these rounds, attending physicians discuss each patient with providers from case management, social work, nursing (attendance by bedside nurses and nurse leaders), physical therapy, and nutrition. These structured sessions allow for a high yield exchange of information including discussion of each patient’s care plan for the day, discharge or special needs and patient safety issues.

Improving Discharge Process

Mt. Zion Discharge Program – Discharge Facilitator and Care Transitions System Utilizing an Interdisiplinary Team Approach

The goals of the program will be to provide education to patients and staff while promoting a patient-centered approach to medication self-management and patient safety. Ultimately the goal will be to ensure a safe discharge plan and significantly reduce subsequent rehospitalization rates. Read more here.

Improving Discharge Process

Post-Discharge Follow-up Clinic

Following hospitalization for an acute illness, most patients require outpatient follow-up in a timely fashion. Due to a myriad of factors, this often proves challenging and creates opportunities for preventable readmissions or return visits to emergency departments. 

The UCSF Screening and Acute Care Clinic (SACC) currently offers a setting for patients to be seen for acute problems when their primary providers are unavailable. SACC also provides a potential setting to develop a bridge for patients after hospitalization if timely access to their primary providers is limited. We propose to establish a Transitional Discharge Clinic (TDC) with dedicated appointments for post-hospitalization follow-up. The TDC appointments will orchestrate discharging teams with providers in SACC to specify the issues that need to be followed, ensure that necessary tests are performed, and communicate these issues to patients’ primary care providers. Read more about the project here.

The Quality Post

Division of Hospital Medicine Quality Improvement Newsletter is designed to share and celebrate our divisional quality improvement (QI) efforts. Our Division has a rich tradition of quality improvement, and we wanted a way to inform the hospitalists and residents about new projects, disseminate data, recognize achievements, and provide important tips on QI leadership.

Job Opportunities

Assistant Assistant III (2 positions open)

The incumbent will serve as the administrative assistant for 10-15 physicians on the Parnassus campus. The AA will provide academic and administrative assistance to the faculty members and handle a wide range of responsibilities associated with the faculty members’ many roles at UCSF. Under the supervision of the Division Administrator, the Administrative Assistant will be responsible for the following tasks: retrieve references from the library; prepare check requests, travel advances and travel vouchers; plan and coordinate complex travel arrangements; distribute and follow up with faculty to resolve UCare notes for correction; provide high level administrative support on special projects and events; maintain supply inventory and place orders as needed; perform word processing; schedule meetings and manage complex calendars; perform photocopying/ faxing; resolve equipment, computer, and pager issues; distribute mail; and provide back-up administrative support for two analysts, one at Parnassus and the other at MZ.

The University of California Regents will implement pay reductions, furloughs and/or other types of measures due to the state budget crisis. This position will be subject to any cost cutting measures implemented at UCSF.

Required Qualifications

High school degree and four years of related administrative experience; or an equivalent combination of education and experience; experience interacting with patients; one-two years bookkeeping or related accounting experience; needs to be organized, detail oriented, ability to keep excellent records, and to effectively juggle competing priorities; one to two years experience reporting to a high level position in higher education, academic setting or company; prior work experience handling confidential information with discretion and tact.   

Excellent customer service to work with various faculty in different levels and different departments; knowledge of Microsoft Outlook, Excel, Access, Word, Powerpoint; ability to work with faculty on high-level, time-sensitive, and detail-oriented projects; ability to multitask and prioritize well; ability to use multiple resources to resolve question/problem at hand; excellent organizational, communication, interpersonal, and customer service skills; proven record of reliability and attendance; ability to work independently and as a team member; demonstrated ability to work effectively under pressure of competing priorities, manage complex scheduling, collaborate with multidisciplinary teams and function as liaison with outside University entities.

Preferred Qualifications

BA degree; knowledge of medical terminology; experience with business and information systems; experience in Powerpoint; prior experience in an academic environment; prior experience with UC systems (Weblinks, PeopleSoft, P2P, Proposal Express, RAS, Cayuse, NIH eRA Commons, and NCIRE ledger reporting system).

Note: Fingerprinting and background check required.

If interested, please submit your CV and 3 references to:

Maria Novelero
533 Parnassus Avenue, Ste U129
UCSF, Box 0131
San Francisco, CA 94143-0131
maria@medicine.ucsf.edu

Job Opportunities

Analyst/Research Assistant

Under the direction of Dr. Steven Pantilat, the UCSF Palliative Care (PC) Program seeks to provide exemplary care to seriously ill patients and their families, educate medical trainees about palliative care, and conduct research. The Palliative Care Service (PCS) Analyst will support the Program’s clinical and educational efforts, as well as coordinate research efforts to assess the palliative care needs of people living with heart failure and other projects.

Duties and Responsibilities

  • Recruiting patients to take part in research activities, and communicating with patients to insure study activities are completed
  • Maintaining meticulous records of study activities and preparing data for analysis
  • Communicating with the UCSF Committee on Human Research (CHR) to insure that research is carried out according to University policy.
  • Assisting with preparation and writing of abstracts and manuscripts for presentation and publication
  • Coordinating the Palliative Care elective for medical students and residents
  • Coordinating PCS team meeting presentations, and generating patient census reports
  • Coordinating the annual patient memorial ceremony and the annual PCS team self-care retreat
  • Ordering brochures and other print supplies for use by PCS patients and UCSF trainees and faculty
  • Supporting research, academic, and scholarly activities of the Palliative Care Program and its Director, Dr. Steven Pantilat
  • Writing, editing and proofreading manuscripts, reports, funding applications and other written materials 

Qualifications

This role incorporates a variety of activities, many of which happen concurrently. The analyst will need to have excellent verbal and written communication skills, stellar analytical, critical-thinking, and organizational skills, and be able to multitask as well as triage tasks to get the job done. It is important that the Analyst be comfortable and competent working independently while maintaining open communication with the PC Program Director. Project management experience is required. While expertise in clinical aspects of palliative care is not required, familiarity with the range of issues addressed by palliative care is essential. Basic skills for data entry and database management and a working knowledge of Microsoft Word, Excel, and Access are necessary.

If interested, please submit a resume or CV that highlights experience that would be relevant to this position and contact information for 3 references that can attest to your interpersonal and organization skills and work ethic to:

Salina Ng
521 Parnassus Avenue, Ste C-126
UCSF, Box 0903
San Francisco, CA 94143-0903
salinang@medicine.ucsf.edu

Clinican-Researcher for Neurosurgery

The UCSF Division of Hospital Medicine (DHM) and the UCSF Department of Neurosurgery are jointly seeking a physician researcher whose primary focus will be in quality/safety in neurosurgery or in surgery/perioperative care more generally. The candidate will be a junior or mid-level faculty member who is board certified in internal medicine and focused on a research career in hospital medicine. This individual will have fellowship training in quality, safety, clinical epidemiology and/or outcomes research (such as through a Robert Wood Johnson or equivalent general medicine or hospital medicine research-oriented fellowship). He or she will have a research agenda that includes improving quality and safety of surgical or perioperative care.

Required skills include data analysis, writing, implementing innovative safety and quality programs, and related areas. The successful candidate will have a joint appointment in the Departments of Medicine and Neurosurgery, with 20% hospitalist clinical work and 80% protected time during the initial years on faculty. Additionally, research seed funding will be made available.

If interested, please submit your letter of interest, CV, and a list of three references to:

Job Opportunities

Click here for DHM Job Board

The UCSF Division of Hospital Medicine hires several new faculty each year into a wide array of positions. Our goal is provide new faculty with a diverse clinical experience that matches their interests while creating opportunities to explore and develop a path for academic success. Most new faculty positions combine clinical experiences on the teaching and non-teaching services as well as some protected time for faculty development. Interested candidates are encouraged to look over the variety of clinical services we offer, as well as our research and educational programs. We would also encourage candidates to read some of our faculty bios to get a sense of the diverse job descriptions. For individuals seeking additional training, we have a number of different fellowship opportunities; you can find more information here. Click here for current job and fellowship opportunities.

Successful candidates for faculty positions will be graduates of excellent internal medicine programs with strong references. Many, but not all, of our faculty have completed a chief residency and/or a fellowship, and have evidence of or potential for skill in teaching and leadership in research, quality improvement, or another academic area. Faculty interested in research-oriented positions (ie, with protected time for research) should have completed a research-intensive fellowship in general or hospital medicine, epidemiology, outcomes, or the like. We strongly encourage applicants from diverse backgrounds or who can make a unique contribution to diversity to apply.

Graduating residents planning to ultimately enter a cardiology/hematology/oncology fellowship who would like to expand their inpatient cardiology/oncology experience or work in an academic environment may be interested in serving on two of our subspecialty hospitalist services: the Advanced Heart Failure (AHF) Hospitalist Service and the Heme-BMT Hospitalist Service. The hospitalists on the AHF/Heme-BMT Hospitalist Service manage the day-to-day care of the patients while the cardiologists/oncologists provide the necessary specialized care. Schedule, hours, and salary are competitive. In addition, hospitalists on our subspeciality services will have the opportunity to get involved in teaching of students and housestaff if interested. The start date for both positions is flexible and we do hire individuals for one-year positions.

Interested applicants for all positions should apply through AP Recruit with a letter of interest, their CV, and three references at the DHM Job Board. Candidates must possess an MD degree, be Board certified/eligible, and be eligible for licensure in the State of California.

Job Opportunities

Hospitalist Clinician-Investigator

The UCSF Division of Hospital Medicine (DHM) is seeking a hospitalist clinician-investigator to join its faculty. DHM has an outstanding track record of developing successful hospitalist clinician-investigators. Our faculty have interests in effective communication strategies, reducing harm from anticoagulant use, and implementing and evaluating quality improvement interventions, among others. Further information about the faculty can be found at http://medicine.ucsf.edu/hospitalists. Research faculty have access to a number of unique resources, such as collaborations through the UCSF Clinical and Translational Sciences Institute, as well as an institutional K award program. Moreover, DHM faculty maintain a number of local and national databases useful to early career researchers.

Candidates must be board eligible/certified in Internal Medicine with excellent clinical and communication skills, and should have completed research fellowship training in general internal medicine or health services research. A track record of publications or presentation of abstracts at national meetings is strongly preferred.

If interested, please submit your letter of interest, CV, and a list of three references to:

Dr. Robert Wachter c/o Mary Whitney at maryw@medicine.ucsf.edu or 415-476-7991

Academic Palliative Medicine Physician

The Palliative Care Program at the University of California, San Francisco (UCSF) Medical Center is seeking a
physician for the role of clinician-educator at the Assistant or Associate level. The position includes patient care, teaching, and scholarly work, as well as opportunities for educational and clinical leadership.

Highlights

• Protected time for academic work and a structured curriculum for faculty career development
• Academic environment with commitment to excellence in patient care, education and research
• Strong research environment and collaborative culture within the Program and Institution that affords unlimited opportunities for interdisciplinary research, program development, academic productivity, and education
• Dedicated and gifted faculty and staff and outstanding trainees at all levels (medical students, residents, and Hospice and Palliative Medicine fellows)
• Institutional culture that is highly receptive and friendly to palliative care
• A supportive and truly interdisciplinary team where each member is an equal contributor
• Inpatient and outpatient Palliative Care Services and rich resources in the community available for collaboration
• Diverse multicultural patient population

The physician will:

• Serve as the Attending Physician on the interdisciplinary Palliative Care Service
• Supervise, train and evaluate medical students, residents, and fellows (partaking in our ACGME-accredited
  Hospice and Palliative Medicine Fellowship Program)
• Participate in scholarly activities in education, program development, quality improvement, and research
• Participate in educational activities at UCSF affiliated hospitals (Moffitt-Long Hospital, Mt. Zion Hospital, San Francisco VA Hospital, and San Francisco General Hospital).

Requirements include:

• Board certification in a primary specialty
• Board-certification or Board-eligibility in Hospice and Palliative Medicine
• Palliative Medicine Fellowship training or other comparable experience
• Vision and initiative to extend the reach of our program and the field of Palliative Care

If interested, please send your CV and three letters of reference to:
Steven Pantilat, MD, Director, UCSF Palliative Care Service, 521 Parnassus Avenue, Suite C-126, UCSF Box 0903. San Francisco, CA 94143-0903 Or email to: ephilipps@medicine.ucsf.edu

Website: http://hospsrvr.ucsf.edu/care/pallcare.htm

PhD Research position in Palliative Care at UCSF

The Palliative Care Research Program (PCRP) at UCSF is seeking a PhD-level researcher to develop and design research projects, write and edit grant proposals and manuscripts, and oversee research teams for the PCRP’s investigators. The Senior Research Coordinator will work collaboratively with PCRP faculty members to provide support and assistance with research project development and management, data management and collection, database development, basic statistical analytic support, and writing.

Duties and Responsibilities

  • Advise on analytic plan and identify further or alternative analyses
  • Contribute to study design and methods
  • Develop background and preliminary data sections for grants
  • Draft and edit research proposals for IRB and funding
  • Carry out basic analyses and interpretation of data
  • Review manuscripts for accuracy and appropriateness of interpretation of results;
  • Identify funding sources for research projects
  • Strategize on next research projects based on results.

Qualifications:

  • A PhD in a social science field, biostatistics, or epidemiology and work experience in clinical or health services research.
  • Technical skills in 1) applied statistics, including parametric and non-parametric statistics, univariate as well as multivariate; 2) database design principles and their application to the management of data sets; and 3) knowledge of personal computer statistical analysis software (SAS, Stata, or similar).
  • Outstanding writing and analytic skills for preparing grant applications, manuscripts and reports.
  • Effective communication/interaction skills for working with investigators, other researchers (both on and off campus) and staff, as well as the ability to effectively supervise research assistants.
  • The ability to work independently and with minimal supervision on several projects simultaneously.
  • Experience managing large databases is helpful.

If interested, please submit your CV and a list of three references to:
Emily Philipps
521 Parnassus Avenue, Ste C-126
UCSF, Box 0903
San Francisco, CA 94143-0903
ephilipps@medicine.ucsf.edu

The mission of the Palliative Care Research Program (PCRP) at UCSF is to improve the quality of life for people living with and dying from serious illness. The PCRP research focuses on professional education and clinical innovations in the care of people with serious and life-threatening illness. Specific research projects include those regarding doctor-patient communication, improving the quality of end-of-life care in hospitals, and palliative care for patients with heart failure.

Research

Wendy Anderson, MD, MS

Wendy Anderson’s research’s main goal is to improve hospital-based end-of-life care by improving communication between physicians and seriously ill patients and their families.  Currently, she is studying communication between hospitalized patients and hospitalists, who provide the majority of inpatient care to seriously ill hospitalized patients in the United States.  

Andrew Auerbach, MD, MPH

Andrew Auerbach's research at UCSF has primarily focused on assessments of patient outcomes in different systems of care, with a special interest in the hospitalist model; Andrew was the UCSF PI for a multicenter study of hospitalist systems, directed the evaluation of the TOPS multicenter study, and leads a number of quality and safety projects examining methods for improving medication management in patients in hospital. Most recently, he has been developing  novel approaches for translating empiric research into clinical practice. Andrew co-directs the UCSF General Internal Medicine Research Fellowship, leads the weekly research incubator session, and actively mentors UCSF faculty involved in translational research across UCSF sites and Departments.

Russell Cucina, MD, MS

Russ Cucina's research is in clinical human-computer interaction science with an emphasis on human factors and patient safety, decision support systems and automated clinical inference, sociotechnical aspects of clinical information systems, information storage and retrieval methods, and knowledge representation and management.

Margaret Fang, MD, MPH

Margaret Fang's research interests focus on evaluating the quality, safety, and outcomes associated with anticoagulation therapy. Her long-term goal is determine how best to use anticoagulants for older adults.

L. Elizabeth Goldman, MD, MCR

A recent general medicine fellowship graduate, Liz Goldman is interested in measuring and improving the quality of hospital care, particularly for underserved populations.

Karen Hauer, MD

Karen Hauer's research interests include mentoring, clinical skills education, and the impact of hospitalists on medical education.

Steven Pantilat, MD

Steven Pantilat has an active research agenda in improving end-of-life care.  He edits an ongoing case-based series on palliative care in JAMA (“Perspectives of Care at the Close of Life”), and has several ongoing research projects measuring palliative care outcomes and quality. 

Sumant Ranji, MD

Sumant Ranji is focused on the application of evidence-based medicine to quality measurement and improvement.  He has been the lead editor of several studies by the Stanford-UCSF Evidence-based Practice Center (EPC) on strategies to close the chasm between evidence-based guidelines and clinical practice.

Niraj Sehgal, MD, MPH

Niraj Sehgal's research interests include patient safety and quality measurement. He's particularly focused on working to improve the collaboration among physicians with nurses, pharmacists, and administrators in designing patient safety interventions and educational methods. One of his overreaching goals is to stimulate and study organizational culture change as a means to providing safer healthcare.  He is leading the “Triad for Optimal Patient Safety” (TOPS) – a three hospital, interdisciplinary study of teamwork and communication skills training to improve safety culture.

Arpana Vidyarthi, MD

As director of quality for the hospitalist group, Arpana Vidyarthi’s research focuses on improving hand-offs, and the impact of resident duty-hours regulations on safety and education. 

Robert M. Wachter, MD

Bob Wachter continues to be interested in organizational change, new models of clinical care (including the hospitalist model), and improving patient safety and quality.  He is collaborating with Niraj Sehgal on the TOPS projects.  He also edits the leading federal patient safety journal (AHRQ WebM&M) and portal (AHRQ PSNet), and is writing a new Lange handbook on patient safety.

Incubator Meetings

The mission of the Division of Hospital Medicine Incubator is to provide a collaborative environment that promotes scholarship for UCSF trainees and faculty.

 

Faculty in the UCSF Division of Hospital Medicine (DHM) pursue broad and diverse interests in teaching, quality improvement, cost reduction, patient safety, global health, palliative care, and clinical research.

The DHM Incubator is a forum where researchers, clinicians, and educators meet to provide tools and guidance necessary to promote scholarly projects across the range of our Division's activities, by connecting individuals with complementary skills and interests and providing necessary mentorship and peer support.

We define scholarship broadly, including evaluation of quality improvement, global health or other health system innovations, as well as advancements in medical education and traditional clinical research.

The Incubator welcomes a broad range of projects, including grant applications, papers, abstracts, and oral presentations, in any phase of preparation.

Questions about the Incubator should be directed to Andy Auerbach or Kirsten Kangelaris. Please contact Sherry Chen for questions related to the Incubator schedule.

Interested in presenting at an Incubator meeting?
Email Andy Auerbach.

Our mission is to improve the health of hospitalized patients through the delivery of high-quality, high-value, evidence-based, and patient-centered care. The Research Core of the UCSF Division of Hospital Medicine advances this mission through promoting the application of rigorous research methods to quality improvement, outcomes assessment, medical education, organizational delivery, and the care of hospitalized patients.

Founded in 1998, the UCSF DHM Research Core holds a remarkable legacy of high-impact contributions to research in hospital medicine. The core faculty currently comprises 6 full-time clinician-investigators and 2 PhD researchers who share a wide range of diverse interests and expertise. In addition, the Research Core supports the larger Divisional research efforts and collaborates closely with the many other active investigators within our group. Members of the Research Core are nationally recognized investigators and have received numerous honors and awards, including through the Society of Hospital Medicine, the American Geriatrics Society, and the Society of General Internal Medicine. The Editor in Chief for the Journal of Hospital Medicine, the flagship journal for our professional society, is the founding director of the Research Core (Dr. Andrew Auerbach).

Faculty in the DHM Research Core have expertise in:

  • Cohort studies and pragmatic clinical trials
  • Outcomes research and pharmacoepidemiology using large databases
  • Applying deep machine learning to electronic health record data
  • Qualitative research, including mixed-methods approaches, focus groups, and one-on-one interviews

The DHM Research Core is actively leading research in the following areas:

  • Hospital-medicine delivery and organization
  • Post-hospitalization outcomes, including readmissions and mortality
  • Patient engagement and health communication
  • Interprofessional education and palliative care
  • Cardiovascular epidemiology and comparative effectiveness outcomes research, particularly in venous thromboembolism, atrial fibrillation, and stroke
  • Pharmacoepidemiology
  • Digital health and the intersection of health information technology with clinical practice

Please click here for the DHM Project Tracker.

DHM Research "Incubator" Program:

The Division of Hospital Medicine Research "Incubator" program was founded in 2008 by Drs. Auerbach and Fang to provide faculty and trainees with research consultancies and expert advice on the conduct of clinical research and scholarly work. The program has successfully supported numerous hospitalist fellows, junior faculty from the Division, and faculty from other departments, including Emergency Medicine and Pediatrics. Hemali Patel (previous Academic Hospital Medicine Fellow), Kirsten Kangelaris, Margaret Fang, James Harrison, Andy Auerbach have published a paper in the Journal of Hospital Medicine describing the DHM's Incubator.

Nebs No More After 24: Appropriate Nebulizer Utilization

Improving Use of Appropriate Respiratory Therapies

Background:

  • Nebulizer treatments are costly and are overused on the medicine service
  • Ample evidence has shown that MDIs are as effective as nebulizers
  • We also have a missed opportunity to teach and train patients to properly use their MDIs while in the hospital

During FY2011, the medicine service spent approximately $500,000 on 16,554 nebulizer treatments for 1000 patients over the course of 8,223 hospital days.

Objectives:

  • To reduce the number of nebulizer treatments outside of the ICU per patient on the medicine service by >15% over a 9-month period without unintended negative clinical outcomes
  • Increase the amount of time spent teaching patients regarding proper MDI self-administration

Interventions:

  Phase 1 (June-August)
  • Remove nebulizer treatments from the "admit order set" in APEX
  • Create an order for RT teaching of MDI use
  • Enlist the RTs and RNs to help with MDI teaching for patients
Phase 2 (September-February)
  • Launch educational program for UCSF medicine attending and resident physicians (posters, handouts, grand rounds facilitation guide, knowledge and attitudes survey)
  • Provide targeted feedback for providers
Phase 3 (October-December)
  • Create an APEX intervention to encourage transitions from nebulizer treatments to MDIs after 24 hours following admission
